abstracts.cdata!:
The Access to Land for Young Farmers
            Project seeks to establish a beneficiary-driven sustainable
            mechanism that would allow poor young farmers acquire, or
            lease productive farm lands, through productive and
            environmentally sustainable on and off-farm investment
            subprojects, that will significantly increase income and
            welfare. The project will thus contribute to an integrated
            rural development strategy that emphasizes the improvement
            of land markets, and promotes rural dynamism. This
            Indigenous Peoples Plan (IPP) ensures that the most
            vulnerable, in particular indigenous populations benefit
            from project implementation, and provides a framework for
            compliance in accordance with the country's legal
            framework, and the Bank's safeguard policies. It
            examines the indigenous locations within the project area,
            the apparent agrarian conflicts in relation to land tenure
            and land rights, and issues relating to land demarcation and
            access to natural resources and water. Recommendations
            suggest a participatory approach, which includes fostering
            public awareness and public consultations. Capacity building
            shall be pursued, as will training and technical assistance,
            in addition to workshops to strengthen community
            participation. Monitoring criteria shall be in place,
            including grievance mechanisms should conflict occur.
